text: i'm neil genzlinger city critic of the
New York Times I recently visited Coney
Island and specifically this place they
are called the scream zone which is new
this year and has four pretty high
intensity rides at it all of them are
perfectly respectable thrill ride the
coolest and most expensive of the new
attractions is called the slingshot
rockets you 150 feet straight up in the
air at 90 miles an hour it's kind of
pricey an individual ticket is twenty
dollars but that was twenty dollars well
spent from my point of view because it's
a completely different experience than
any rollercoaster you've ever been on
and it gives you a fantastic view of
Coney Island when you're up at the top
of the arc none of these new attractions
are cheap my daughter and I spent a
total of sixty dollars and rode three
rides each but they're not that much
more expensive than the older rides like
the cyclone and if like me you can only
tolerate one or two of these big ride in
a single afternoon then Coney Island
ends up being a little cheaper than a
place like six flags
these new rides are kind of high-tech
but Coney Island as a whole still feels
very much like a throwback there was a
lot of talk when the rides were
announced that they were going to
displace some older attractions and the
Coney Island was going to lose its
historical feel I did not find that to
be the case the Wonder Wheel is still
there the cyclone is still there plenty
of other old-school attractions are
still there and the place still has a
very laid-back and gritty and urban feel
down the block from the scream zone
there is an interesting little history
museum that you can get into for a
dollar and the displays there really
drive home the fact that Coney Island
has actually changed quite a bit over
the years a century ago there were these
huge spectacles there with casts and
numbering in the hundreds and animals
and dwarves and everything else you
don't see that today and I think these
new rides are just another step in that
evolution and yet the overall feel is
still absolutely uniquely Coney Island
Brooklyn
